section.hand:
Copie of a letter to my L. Treasuro
r
A
p
29.
89

lettertext.section: Belgia 1589 29 Aprill To my L Treasurer
lettertext.hand:
It may please yo
r
L. It hath hapned since
my last to yo
r
L.
at three Cornets of horse,
going out of
Hoesden,
to cut of a Convoy of
e
Ennemie, folowed their prey so farre, as in
e
retrait
e Ennemie, being strong of 400 horse,
and 500 footmen, sett uppon them in a streite
passage, and killed a great part, taking al-
most all
e rest prisoners. The first on sett
was given by
Neus,
e chief mutiner of
Ger-
trudenbergh
. One of
e cornets belonged to
Count
Maurice
, an other to
Villiers,
and
e third to
Kintzky,
being accounted
e 3 best
at we had.
Their adventure is generally condemned, con-
sidering
e strength of
e ennemie in every cor-
ner of those quarters, and
e want of footmen to
succo
r
them, or assurance of any retrait. So
that nowe there are not left in these Provinces
twice so many horses besides: and Hoesden is
very muche weakned by it, having in it at
this p
nt
but 600 men, wheras 1600 are thought
w
t
e fewest, for defense of
e towne. Wherup-
pon it is feared, that he will make thither out
of hand: having brought to
Langhestraet
great
stoare of artillerie. Moreover
e dickes about
Hemerts Weert
, are in divers places dried up
and passable, wherby it is in daunger, and
then
Bommel
like to folowe: where
e people
are more then half discontented already.
Also
e ennemie hath taken very lately
e
Beeke,
wherby Berche, and
Bli enbleeke
are like to fall
into their handes: and then after no dout he will
towardes
Arnham
and
Utrecht,
where
e people
waver, and give manifest tokens, as if they
sought an alteration. They of
Rossendale,
fol.176v
and
Steenberghen
have taken of late at one time
at
e Plate, uppon
e passage between
Holland
and
Zeland,
six marchants shippes of this contrey.

The duke causeth both at those 2 places & at
Gertrudenbergh
a great nomb
r
of big boates to be made w
th
w
ch
yt is feared
he will so fill all
t
passage as hardly any ship shal passe
w
th
out a chargeable convoy: w
ch
doutles will put
is people in a
great discontentment for want of theyr usuall traffique,
Heer is order taken for remforcing of all
eir garrisons
and for
e levieng of 15 comp
s
more, but
ey know not where
to fynde souldiers: all men being weary of theyr hard
enterteynment, in so much as certayn
t
were raysed of late
at
Dordrecht
refused openly to take othe to
e States, but onely
to
Count Maurice
&
e Towne of Dordrecht. The states ar
buisied at this p
nt
in setting downe Instructions for theyr deputies
w
ch
they send to hir Ma
tie
, howbeyt they do keepe them so secret
to them selves, as I cannot by any meanes learne what they are.
But in private conference w
ch
I have had of late w
th
M
r
Valcke
I might
ceave
t
e authority of hir Ma
ties
g
nal
wilbe a special
point of theyr charge: and it should seeme by his speeches
t
they will resolve to yeeld as much autority unto him as her
H
nes
will demaund. Wherupon I told him
t
it was demaunded
alredy in
e declara
o
n w
ch
I p
nt
ed to
e general States upon
theyr new Instructions to
e counsel of State. w
ch
did
manifestly notifie
e Generals autoritye. Against those
Instructions of
e States there hath no man heer at any
tyme bin more earnest, then M
r
Valcke himself. And though
both he &
Loozen
& many others ar of
em selves very indifer
e
t
& dislike altogeth
r
of
e course
at is taken in many things
heer, yet
ey will not dare to passe
t
co
m
ission
t
they shall
receyve, w
ch
for ought I can perceave ys not like to be so
ample, as were requesit. If yo
r
L. upon
e presenta
o
n
of yt & of all theyr propositions, shal think good to send
hether a Copy of them I will retourne a p
nt
aunswer &
somewhat perhaps wilbe signified, wherof yo
r
L. may desire
to be enformed. I might conjecture by Valck
t
they ar
rath
r
desirous to have a g
nall
heer for hir Ma
ty
then oth
r
wise
because they ar persuaded, they shall never oth
r
wise be able to
keepe hir Ma
ties
people in any good disciplyne. as I see many
tokens for myne owne part, to think them in a right opinion
fol.177v
Ortels
motion for an allowance to be made in mony in Lieu of hir
Ma
ties
forces, seemed by his talke to be disliked of heere, for
that they nev
r
willed him from hence to proceed to
t
offer
neyther do I Judge
t
they will harken unto yt, esteeming
the very name & counten
n
ce of hir Ma
ties
protection as greate a
benefyt as
e assistance yt self. yt appeared also by him
that they will send two marchants to accompany theyr deputies
& to deale in
e matt
r
of traffique. wherin he affirmed
t
they can make achount of more then three hun
d
tho
w
poundes
sterling
t
they ar the worse by
England
w
th
in
es fowr yeares.
I do not think I told him
t
they can make
t
reconing
sum: but I thought yt would be easy for hir Ma
ty
to make
evident demonstra
o
n
at
e fournishing of
e Ennemy out of
these countryes w
th
munition & other necassaries, hath bin an
occasyon to hir highnes of spending twice as much as
t
somme
&
e principall occasyon of
e prolongation of
es warres.
